ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SINGAPORE DOLLAR


    1. Mr Shriniwas Rai asked the Prime Minister, in the light of the Indonesian Government's decision to go ahead with the currency board, what steps would the Singapore Government take to see that the Singapore dollar does not suffer as a result of the fall in the Indonesian rupiah.

Column: 448

DEPRECIATION OF CURRENCIES OF NEIGHBOURING COUNTRIES
(Effect on Singapore's competitiveness)


    2. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Deputy Prime Minister how the relative depreciation of the currencies of Singapore's neighbouring countries will affect our competitiveness.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I will answer Question Nos. 1 and 2 together.

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

Column: 449



    BG Lee Hsien Loong: The depreciation of the regional currencies relative to the Singapore dollar will have some impact on our export competitiveness. But we should take a broader perspective. First, the Singapore dollar has depreciated against the US dollar and most European currencies since July last year. On an overall trade-weighted basis, the Singapore dollar has been stable.

    Second, we are not direct competitors with the ASEAN economies in most product categories. An internal MAS study shows that, for both goods and services, our major competitors in the region are the NIEs, and within ASEAN, Malaysia. The Singapore dollar has not appreciated against the Hong Kong or Taiwanese currencies.

    Third, what matters to our export competitiveness is the real exchange rate, namely, the nominal rate, which is then adjusted for cost or inflation differentials between us and our trading partners. The sharp depreciation of the regional currencies will eventually raise domestic prices in these economies and erode the initial gains in competitiveness.

    Fears that a fall in the Indonesian rupiah will drag the Singapore dollar down are at this stage hypothetical. The Indonesian government has not yet decided to set up a currency board system.

    The Singapore dollar should not be unduly affected by movements in the Indonesian rupiah. Indonesia's exports do not compete with Singapore's exports. The weight of the rupiah in our basket is small. Furthermore, our exchange rate policy is not mechanically driven by the trade weights. MAS exercises judgment in managing the exchange rate, and takes into account exceptional market factors. MAS will maintain confidence in the Singapore dollar, by intervening in the foreign exchange market where necessary.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, may I ask the Deputy Prime Minister, with the lowering of the currency rates in our neighbouring countries, like in Indonesia and Malaysia, and therefore they have become more competitive and enjoy

Column: 450

low manufacturing cost, would the promotion of the Growth Triangle concept be more useful?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, yes, indeed, the Growth Triangle concept is useful and the lower cost in the neighbouring provinces of Malaysia, Indonesia, Johor and Riau, should enable our businesses and companies which have operations there also to benefit from this lower cost. But, as I explained earlier, it is the real exchange rate which determines our competitiveness, not the nominal one.

    Let me explain the difference. If we trade with Indonesia and the rupiah goes down from 2,500 rupiah to 10,000 rupiah, other things being equal, Indonesian costs have gone down four times and therefore they are four times more competitive than us. But other things do not remain equal. When the rupiah goes down, imports cost more, people are unable to pay, they agitate for higher wages, and wages go up, inflation goes up. And if, for the sake of argument, the rupiah has gone down four times but prices have gone up four times in Indonesia, then although there has been a nominal depreciation of their currency, there is no real effect on our competitiveness or their competitiveness. It will not completely work out like that. It takes some time, and at the end of it, I think our neighbouring countries will end up somewhat more competitive than we are, but not to the extent as shown just by looking at the exchange rates now.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Sir, does the Deputy Prime Minister think that, in light of the fact that probably there will be a real exchange rate devaluation among the regional countries, actually competitiveness will be a bigger issue for us now and particularly in the medium term after these Asian economies recover than before, let us say, July of last year?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: I think it will vary from industry to industry. Overall, yes, it will be offset somewhat because we have become more competitive compared to, say, developed countries, and the developed countries were, to some extent, competing against us for investments and exports. But against the neighbouring

Column: 451

countries, they will end up somewhat more competitive than us, particularly our more labour-intensive industries. The older plants which have been here for some time - mass production, very low margins - will be under pressure and adjustments will have to be made.

    At the upper end, the effect on us is not so much on the cost as on the state of the markets, and some of those have been affected too, particularly where they export to the region or where the region has a big influence on world prices. For example, with petrochemicals, when the region boomed it was a big consumer and now that the region is down, prices are down. Some of our projects are going to see investors reconsidering them, and maybe deferring them for some time. But it is part of being in an economic slowdown.

Column: 451

RETRENCHED WORKERS
(Particulars)


    3. Mr Lim Swee Say asked the Minister for Labour (a) how many workers were retrenched in 1997; (b) on average, how long these retrenched workers took to find new employment; (c) whether older workers take a longer time than younger workers in securing new employment; and (d) how his Ministry will help retrenched workers, especially those who are unskilled and not-so-young, to find employment.

Column: 451

RATE OF UNEMPLOYMENT


    4. Mr Chuang Shaw Peng asked the Minister for Labour what is the current rate of unemployment and whether this rate is rising rapidly and, if so, how the Government plans to address this problem.

    The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, with your permission, may I take both Question Nos. 3 and 4 together?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, in 1997, 9,784 workers were retrenched. This was 11% lower than the 10,956 laid off in 1996.

Column: 452

However, the number of workers retrenched has increased since the onset of the regional economic crisis. In the fourth quarter of 1997, 4,278 workers were retrenched, compared to 5,506 during the first three quarters of the year.

    Total employment in Singapore increased by 122,800 in 1997 compared with 102,600 in 1996. The economy continued to enjoy full employment as reflected in the low unemployment rate of 1.8% for the whole of 1997. However, the last quarter of 1997 saw higher unemployment rate of 2% reflecting the increased retrenchments during that quarter. Fortunately, for most of 1997, we experienced strong employment growth and a tight labour market. Many retrenched workers found alternative employment quickly. Based on CPF's records, 79% of the local workers retrenched during the first three quarters of 1997 were re-employed by December 1997. The re-employment rate for older workers aged 50 and above was lower at 66%.

    Among the workers who were re-employed, the average time taken to secure new jobs was 1.8 months after being retrenched. There was no significant difference in the average time for workers in the various age groups.

    As a result of the on-going regional economic crisis and a less than vigorous rebound in certain sectors of the electronics industry, we saw more retrenchments since the beginning of this year. As the economy is likely to grow at a slower pace this year, we are also expecting more retrenchments for the rest of the year. My Ministry has therefore decided to set up a Tripartite Panel comprising representatives from EDB, NTUC, SNEF, PSB and the Ministry itself to assist retrenched workers seeking re-employment. Retrenched workers who are older or lacking in skills will have to make special efforts to acquire useful skills or upgrade their skills to improve their employability. The Tripartite Panel will also look into ways of assisting such workers.

Column: 453

EMPLOYMENT ACT
(Compensation to long-service employees whose services are
terminated)


    5. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Labour whether the Government will consider amending the Employment Act to require employers to pay compensation to employees who are terminated by the companies that they had served for ten years or more.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe) (for the Minister for Labour): Sir, an employee's service may be terminated for a variety of reasons such as poor work performance, ill health or redundancy. Under any of these circumstances, the employer is required to give notice of termination or salary in lieu of notice. Notice of termination is usually provided in the employment contract. In the absence of such a provision, the period of notice will be in accordance with the Employment Act.

    Where an employee's service is terminated on ground of poor work performance, he will not be given compensation. In the case of an employee whose service is terminated on ground of ill health, his employer would usually grant an ex-gratia payment to assist him financially. For termination on ground of redundancy, an employee who is covered by the Employment Act is eligible to claim for retrenchment benefit if he has a minimum of 3 years' service.

    The Employment Act does not stipulate the quantum of retrenchment benefits payable. We have taken this approach to enable companies and the affected employees to have greater flexibility in determining the appropriate amount, taking into account the financial position of the company. Thus, the quantum of retrenchment benefit payable for a non-unionised employee is subject to negotiation with his employer. Where a non-unionised employee is dissatisfied with his compensation, he can always appeal to my Ministry for assistance. My Ministry's Labour Relations Department will, through conciliation, help the

Column: 454

employee to pursue claim for retrenchment payment. In the case of a unionised employee, the amount of retrenchment benefit is determined through collective bargaining between the union and the company.

    The prevailing retrenchment benefit payable to affected workers in the non-unionised sector varies from a few days' salary for each year of service to one month's salary for each year of service. In the case of the unionised sector, the norm of retrenchment benefit payable is two weeks to one month's salary for each year of service, unless the financial position of the company warrants a lower quantum.

    In practice, the quantum of retrenchment benefit stipulated in collective agreements is higher compared to the quantum paid to those who are not unionised. This in itself is an incentive for workers to join trade unions. It should also be pointed out that employees with less than 3 years' service, while not eligible to claim for retrenchment benefit, are in practice also paid some form of ex-gratia payment.

    As the law already enables a retrenched employee with 3 years' service to claim retrenchment benefit and affected workers are paid such benefit based on the financial position of the company or in accordance with the collective agreements, the suggestion by the Member for Hougang that employers pay retrenchment benefit to employees with at least 10 years' service, is not in the interest of workers.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, is the Minister of State aware that there are employees whose services are terminated by the employer giving just one month's notice or in lieu of notice, paying one month's salary without any further compensation? I think such cases have been referred to the Ministry before.

    Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: Sir, as I have stated, if he is a non-unionised employee and he is not satisfied with the retrenchment payment, he can appeal and seek assistance from the Labour Relations Department of my Ministry. In the case of unionised employees, it is based

Column: 455

on the negotiations between the union and the company. As I have mentioned earlier, in most cases, the practice for unionised employees is that they can at least have two weeks to one month's salary for each year of service as compensation. But this depends on the financial position of the company. I am not sure which particular case the Member is referring to. In the case where a company has no money, there cannot be any retrenchment payment. So it depends on the financial position of the company and the circumstances of the retrenchment exercise.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Generally, do employers need to specify the reason for termination in their letter of termination or they just say, "Under the contract, I terminate your employment."?

    Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: Sir, in the case of retrenchment, the employer will mention to his employee that because of very poor business conditions or some other reasons there has to be a retrenchment. In the case of a unionised company, the union will be informed of any retrenchment that is necessary because of these reasons.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: A clarification, Sir. I am referring to termination, not necessarily retrenchment. The employer may just terminate an employee's services by giving him one month's notice, or in lieu of notice, paying one month's salary without specifying any reason. Is there anything under the Employment Act which could compel an employer to specify the reasons for termination?

    Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: Under the law, the employer has to give a notice of termination. But whether or not he gives the reasons for termination depends on the circumstances of the case. If it is poor conduct or poor performance, then the employer may want to give that reason. But it depends on the circumstances of the case.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: In the case of an employer not stating any reason at all, would the employee concerned be able to claim any compensation?

Column: 456



    Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: Sir, there is a termination clause. The employee can also terminate his services and he does not need to give a reason. If he finds another job, he just says, "Okay, I want to leave the company." Since there is a termination clause and the employer wants to terminate the services of his employee, he can also exercise it on the same basis. So it is not necessary for him to give a reason if he does not want to, because it is on a reciprocal basis. The employee can also give notice of termination. If he finds a better job, he does not need to give a reason to the employer. Likewise, it is up to the employer. In the case of retrenchment, and that was the Question filed, obviously in the case of a unionised company, the union would be informed and it will then negotiate on the type of retrenchment benefit or payment that should be paid, and this is based on the financial position of the company.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Does the Minister of State appreciate that the present laws in Singapore and the practices followed by his Ministry leave the worker entirely on the charity of the employer as to how much compensation he is to be paid? The Minister of State says that it will not protect the workers to legislate for payment of compensation for workers who have been employed for 10 years or more. Why will it not? May I ask the Minister of State when will this Government bring in an Unfair Termination Act so that an employee who feels that his services have been terminated unfairly may have it referred and reviewed by a board, quite outside the Ministry, who will then decide what compensation is to be paid to the employee?

    Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: Sir, I have already explained that under the current law there is adequate protection for all employees, and if an employee needs any help he can come to the Ministry. Under the law, if a worker has worked for more than three years, he can claim for retrenchment benefit. He does not have to work for 10 years. That was made very clear. If there is any problem relating to the amount of compensation paid, he can appeal to the Ministry of

Column: 457

Labour, but the amount of compensation payable is dependent on the financial position of the company. If the company is doing well and retrenches its workers for reasons other than being insolvent, then the Ministry will have to look at the amount of compensation that should be paid. The norm is from two weeks to one month's salary for each year of service for companies which are able to pay. So there is adequate protection under the law and I do not think we need to make any changes at this stage.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I say to the Minister of State that I was not asking about retrenchment, but about workers whose services are terminated and the law, as I know it, does not require the employer to give any reasons. If he does not like the man's face, he can terminate his services by giving him a month's notice. So what is the protection? Why do we not have an Unfair Termination Board?

    Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: Sir, first, I have mentioned earlier that it applies to both employer and employee. The employee can also send in his letter of termination and he need not give any reasons.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: That is not an answer.

    Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: Second, if the employee feels that his services have been unfairly terminated, he can appeal to the Ministry which will look into the reasons for termination. He can appeal to the Minister who will ask for an inquiry to be conducted. Both parties will be invited to the Ministry. The Ministry will study the reasons. If it is unfair, the Ministry will ask the employer to take whatever action that is needed. The law provides for this and I do not see why the Member is raising this matter.

Column: 457

CRASH OF SILKAIR MI185
(Status of investigation)


    6. Mr Chuang Shaw Peng asked the Minister for Communications what is the status of investigation on the crash of SilkAir MI185; whether there is any

Column: 458

evidence or suspicion of foul play; and whether families of the victims are fairly compensated.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Sir, investigations on the crash by a team of Indonesian, Singaporean and American experts are in progress, both in the United States and Indonesia. The task is made more difficult by the lack of useful data from the two black boxes, despite extensive efforts by investigators from the United States National Transportation and Safety Bureau (NTSB) and other expert agencies. The investigation team is headed by Indonesia and includes representatives from Singapore, the US and Australia. It will meet in Jakarta soon to review the status of the investigation and to work out a plan for the subsequent investigation task. These tasks include laboratory examination of wreckage pieces, reconstruction of parts of the aircraft, flight simulations using computers of flight simulators, study of the human performance aspects, review of flight and maintenance documents and further analysis of data from the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder. We hope that this phase of the investigation will provide us some clues to the cause of this tragic incident.

    On the question of foul play, so far, the team has not uncovered any evidence and there is no suspicion of foul play. On the matter of compensation, I am informed by SilkAir that their lawyer is currently liaising with the legal next-of-kin of the deceased. Compensation will be paid in accordance with the contract of carriage under international aviation regulations.

    Dr Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether he would consider calling a press conference of the experts who can perhaps brief the public and the press on some of these issues.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, as I said in my reply just now, the experts will be reconvening in Jakarta some time next week. After they have formulated the next phase of their investigation, I will request them to hold a press briefing to explain the status of the investigation so far, from the experts' point of view, and also to brief the public on what it intends to do in the next phase.

Column: 459

DIVESTMENT OF GOVERNMENT-LINKED COMPANIES


    7. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked the Minister for Finance, in light of the fundamental dilemma of public accountability versus entrepreneurial risk-taking which Government-Linked Companies (GLCs) face, as well as the Government's long-term intention of full divestment of those companies with commercial activities, whether the Government will consider accelerating the full divestment of some GLCs or some of the businesses of GLCs by schemes such as Management Buy-Outs.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Sir, in principle, the Government is prepared to divest fully its stakes in the GLCs other than those of strategic interest to our defence or our economy. Other than these strategic investments, the rest can be privatised in due course. However, apart from the obvious considerations of market conditions, the pricing and the capacity of the market to absorb the divestments, there are a number of other considerations in deciding whether we can accelerate the process of divestment. In particular, the Government has put in much effort and resources to develop the GLCs, and we would want to divest them in such a way that the issue of management succession is properly addressed and that there will be either a single shareholder or a group of shareholders with a significant stake to provide management direction and to grow the company. This is important as Government would want the GLC to remain in relatively good hands. Government has also to be fair to the other minority shareholders of the GLC and be mindful that its divestments do not have too adverse an impact on the future of the company. This requirement will, however, slow down the divestment process.

    Management Buy-Outs (MBOs) are not ruled out as a divestment method for GLCs where the Government has a direct stake. MBO is possible if there is interest as well as a willingness to take the business risk on the part of the companies' management and agreement

Column: 460

on reasonable terms of sale. However, the size of the GLCs often makes them beyond the financial resources of managements. Nevertheless, besides MBOs, other approaches of divestment had been, and will be, considered when the terms of sale are reasonable. Government will continue to pursue its privatisation and divestment programme in an orderly manner as and when the opportunity presents itself.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan:Sir, in terms of the Government divestment programme, does the Government also intend to divest management, and not merely corporatisation? In other words, is it the Government's intention to have a full divestment, including that of management?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I do not quite understand the Member. By divesting management, does she mean that Government has no longer any responsibility? You are talking about the difference between corporatization -

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Corporatisation and full divestment in terms of management.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Yes, we have, in most cases, gone the route of full divestment without residual management control. I will give you a few examples of companies which we have fully divested and only retained a minimal control. In the case of Singapore Press Holdings, it has been fully divested, except that Government holds a golden share because it is a sensitive area. National Iron and Steel Mill has been totally divested. It is in the hands of the public and it has its own management. The others are UIC, Phillips Petroleum of Singapore and so forth. So there are many areas where we have totally divested.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Sir, I may be wrong, but it would seem to me that the shares of many of these GLCs belong to holding companies that are in turn actually owned by the Government.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: There are some. Can you name some specific companies that you are concerned about?

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: As far as I know, I think Temasek Holdings actually holds a substantial number of shares in many of

Column: 461

the companies that you have mentioned. To that extent, Temasek Holdings actually would have a substantial say in terms of the management direction of the company.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: For those where it retains significant shareholdings, yes. But for those in which it does not hold substantial shareholdings, it would not.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): The Minister has mentioned that the Government has still got some residual control of SPH. Can I know what sort of control?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: No single person or company can hold more than 3% of SPH shares. And Government holds one golden share to ensure that no third party can take over the company because of the sensitivity of its operations. That is all that is controlled. So financially, as far as the commercial operations are concerned, Government has no control over it.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: What does the Minister mean by "golden share"?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: One nominal share, but that share has overriding powers over the management of the company. In other words, it can determine the Chairman and the Board.

I REVIEW OF THE ECONOMY

ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE IN 1997



    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore economy grew by a robust 7.8% in 1997. However, this did not reflect the seriousness of the ongoing regional economic turmoil which started in July last year.

    Economic growth in 1997 was largely shaped by two factors. First, we benefited from the recovery in the global electronics industry. Corrections in inventory overhang and healthy new orders in US and Europe boosted export demand, and confirmed our earlier assessment that the slowdown we experienced in the second half of 1996 was primarily cyclical. This turnaround provided the fillip for the manufacturing sector. We expected this.

    But nobody expected the second factor - the spread and subsequent deepening of the economic crisis in the region. The speed and severity of contagion caught everyone off-guard. What started off as a devaluation of the Thai Baht led to widespread financial and economic turbulence in the region. One after another, regional

Column: 527

    Fortunately, the impact on the real economy in 1997 was muted. There were two primary reasons for this. First, a large part of Singapore's regional trade consists of intra-firm movement of parts, components and final products by multi-national companies (MNCs) for export to end markets in the OECD countries. As final demand from the US and EU was healthy, Singapore's overall trade was not too seriously affected by the regional crisis. Second, the upswing in global electronics demand also supported our manufacturing growth, generating favourable spin-offs for our related hub services.

ECONOMIC OUTLOOK FOR 1998


    The regional crisis is far from over. While its impact on us in 1997 was minimal, the same cannot be said for 1998. Being at the heart of South East Asia, we are not isolated from regional conditions. We have comprehensive economic linkages with the region and a strong stake in our neighbours' prosperity. In particular, our tradable services sectors like finance and tourism have a strong regional orientation and will be directly affected.

    It is useful to review how the regional crisis started and spread, assess its impact on the Singapore economy and businesses, and identify the measures which the Government, companies and Singaporeans can take to tide over this difficult period.

What Caused the Crisis

    The roots of the crisis can be traced back to the huge influx of cheap foreign capital to the region in the early 1990s. With inadequate prudential supervision, regional financial institutions over-extended themselves and lent excessively, often to unproductive sectors and projects. This rapid build up of foreign debt was not sustainable. It created asset bubbles in the property and stock markets. For a time, strong regional economic

Column: 528

    Confidence in the region's export potential began to waver towards the mid-1990s, with various exchange rate realignments. In 1994, China devalued the Yuan. In 1995 the Japanese Yen started depreciating against the greenback. In countries whose currencies were tightly pegged to the US dollar, exports began to lose competitiveness. Economies such as China and Latin America emerged as keen competitors. These developments coincided with a cyclical downturn in the global electronics industry and precipitated a regional export slowdown in 1996.

    With the export engines stalled, investors and creditors grew nervous of the regional countries' continued ability to service the growing foreign debt burden. Eventually, the market lost faith in the sustainability of the linked exchange rate systems adopted by regional economies.

    Thailand was the first to suffer this loss of investor confidence. Speculative attacks against the Baht mounted as concerns about the Thai economy grew. The breaking point came when Thailand's foreign reserves dipped below its short-term foreign debt obligations in the middle of 1997. Without sufficient reserves to defend its currency, the Thai Government was forced to allow the Baht to float on 2nd July 1997. The contagion effect of this de-facto devaluation of the Thai Baht quickly spread to Malaysia and Indonesia as the market switched its attention to other Southeast Asian economies with similar structural weaknesses in their financial and banking systems.

    By September, the financial crisis extended to North East Asia. Hong Kong's US dollar peg came under severe pressure, but managed to hold. Long standing structural weaknesses in Japan's financial and banking system caused some major institutions to fail. South Korea, with weaker fundamentals and large private sector debt, took the biggest hit. A massive US$57 billion IMF-led bail-out package was necessary to stabilise the Won, and to keep the Korean economy on its feet.

Transport and Logistics

    Our transport and logistics network has played a pivotal role in Singapore's development as a global city of international trade. Today, the transport and logistics sector contributes 9% to GDP and employs more than 110,000 workers or about 7% of our work force. As an industry which provides essential support to our trade sector, it needs to constantly evolve new and improved services to meet the demands of the trade. Our continued growth as a global city of international trade and hub port also depends critically on the development of a transport and logistics sector with extensive networks. To encourage major transport and logistics operators to further expand their businesses in Singapore and use Singapore as a base for their operations, I have therefore decided to introduce the following tax concessions:

(a) Tax Exemption for Income Derived from Uplift of Freight

    Currently, tax is levied on the uplift of cargoes from Singapore, except for Singapore-flagged vessels and vessels from countries with which Singapore has signed a tax treaty. To further boost Singapore's development as an international cargo and shipping hub, I have decided to exempt non-resident ship owners and charterers from tax on their freight uplift from Singapore. CONCLUSION


    Mr Speaker, Sir, the events since July 1997 have shown how quickly the regional environment can turn unfavourable. The policy measures introduced in this budget are based on our assessment of the present state of the Singapore economy and the outlook for the year. They assume that no major changes will occur in the external economic environment which will affect us drastically. But we cannot be certain how the situation will develop. The Government will monitor the regional environment and economic conditions vigilantly, and keep in close touch with the private sector. If the picture changes, we are ready to implement further measures promptly. We have the resources to do so. We cannot totally neutralise the fallout from the regional crisis, but we will do everything possible to offset its impact on Singapore.

    Businesses and individuals must prepare themselves for a period of slower growth and uncertainty. They must be ready to respond to unanticipated developments, and not flinch from tough measures where warranted. Our best approach is to acknowledge the realities of the situation, however adverse they may be. This maximises our chances of surmounting the problems. It also demonstrates to investors and analysts our preparedness to tackle problems directly rather than evading them. This adds to confidence in Singaporeans and in Singapore.

    If we stay united in tackling the problems which come our way, we will strengthen our competitiveness, ride out the crisis, and emerge stronger than before.
